header.product: Levinsohn Greek New Testament Discourse Features
header.name: annotations

references.reference: Never arthrous in nominative.
Norm, whether adjectival (preceding head noun) or functioning as a substantive, to be anarthrous.
Default position following auxiliary.
Refocus on established info (see command of v 20).
Preferred analysis (P2) because anarthrous.
Preferred analysis (P1) because arthrous, accessible because of association with fire and judgement (see Malachi 4:1 on burning up evildoes like stubble).
Default position is after verb (19/35).
May be default order, with estin as an enclitic.
Marked position of panta; see Mt 6:32 vs 33.
Default position between Aux and V.
Behaves like a verb, as far as constituent order is concerned.
Treated as a VP. When the copula is present, makarios/i always precedes it.
Marks closure of sub-unit.
Topic accessible from 'treasures', rather than thetic.
Dia touto falls on the border between connectives and PoDs. I have chosen not to mark it as a situational PoD, unless it is preceded by a conjunction.
Marked because governs autwn, not the verb.
Default: hapas initial in phrase.
Default position
Marked position of panta (contrast v 32).
Treating the adjective as verb-like.
Elision of final constituent is from the first clause, as per the typological principle (see Whaley p. 274).
Always pre-verbal.
In Jn, judged to be focal (see 19:10-11).
HP points forward to next episode ('follow me' ... 'this disciples followed him ... into the storm').
Default position for Synoptics.
Usually pre-N
Articular: those alluded to in v 16.
Pre-verb is the default position of palai.
Default position with copula?
Answering question of v 10, so the same order is reproduced.
Pre-verbal position appears to be default.
Usually pre-N,
Arthrous cos of ref in 18.
If construction is cleft.
Focally prominent.
Could be a cleft construction with the subject in P1 in the second part.
Could be in P2 as part of next clause.
Always pre-verbal.
Default position of notional subject is after auxiliary,
The dative pronoun always precedes dokei in Matthew.
In spite of the articular variant in Mk 10:31b, I take this to be thetic: 'there will be many first who will be last, and last, first'.
'& you will receive whatever you ask for in prayer / if you believe' (NLT, adapted).
Norm is pre-vb.
Preposed; compare v 31.
Domain of adverb: whole proposition.
The focus is on 'with', rather than 'with you', since 'you' is established.
Chiasm, rather than embedded DFE?
Default order would had the participle after 'the heavens'.
Indefinite plural (Wallace).
Variants have the order different, to conform to Mt & Lk. If this phrase relates to 'has authority', then it has been postposed.
'There is no-one who...' (thetic).
Inciting event
OR noun incorporation (Matthew has sumbulion lambano).
Normally pre-echein (incorporated).
In Mark, default appears to be after the verb.
Topical in thetic clause.
Foil for subject of next clause?
Norm is for pas to be anarthrous, though ta panta is quite common, especially in Pauline epistles.
Barclay treats the initial constituent as focal, not a PoD: 'What you get depends on what you give -only more so'.
Mark places focal constituents before the negative elsewhere, too (e.g., 8:17).
Compare 9:8.
NRSV treats this as a PoD.
NB Impf.
Occurs six times: five times before the verb and once (Phil 2:23) aftrer it. I am assuming that the pre-verbal position is default.
Could be in P2 as part of next clause.
Narrow focus, replacing 'apparition'.
Default position of lian is after the constituent that it itensifies.
Concessive: nevertheless
Default order is N + modifying participial clause.
NB aorist
NB impf.
Hapax, so not possible to establish whether this is its default position.
Default position is pre-verb.
Marked usage, added implicatures (perhaps anticipating v 32).
V - named S - pronominal object order is consistent with this being marked as a decisive intervention by Peter.
If focal, I'd have expected it to follow ou.
In contrast with Mt 19, 'the Kingdom of God' has not been established in the immediate context, hence the ambiguity.
Alternatively, 'me' could be contrasting with 'no-one except God'.
Established info. Ditto in v 24.
In spite of the articular variant in 31b, I take this to be thetic: 'there will be many first who will be last, and last, first'.
Default position for subject of periphrastic construction: between copula and participle.
If present, default position for object of 'wish' = subject of 'do'.
Could also be focally prominent.
If 'the way of God' is established info (see Mt 22:16), then it is not focal, but has been pulled forward by the other focal constituent.
Marked cos reverse order in Mk 9:8 (also 5:3).
Or 'WHYEVER are you causing her troubles?' with ti focally prominent.
Reading this as: 'Why is it that to,her you cause TROUBLES?'
Narrow focus; answers the question of v 12.
Default is ouketi without further negative particles.
See NEB 'Day after day I was within your reach as I taught in the temple' (contrast NRSV 'Day after day I was with you in the temple teaching').
Marked as focally prominent, rather than topical, because of Lk 22:58.
Or incorporated? (Mk 3:6 has a different verb, and Mt uses lambano (5x).)
Domain of adverb: whole proposition.
Default position.
Default position of lian is after the constituent it intensifies.
The relative clause is focally prominent within the PP.
It is not normal to split a PoD. Is the sentence thetic, or does the splitting give prominence to 'all the multitude'?
The rest of the clause is established info.
Default position for interrogative.
Or exophoric. Either way, the hina clause relates back to it.
Not initial in Mark 13:36.
Foil for the shepherds.
Norm for such comments is just the proxminal demonstrative (e.g. Lk 8:41, 23:51-52).
Not treated as a postposed topical subject, because peri panto:n ... pone:ro:n is a split focal constituent.
Order as in LXX, but not in Hebrew.
Always pre-verb, though could well be focally prominent.
Similar to v. 20b. Luke seems to be emphasising 'everyone in the synagogue'.
Why post-verbal? (In A, C: pre-verbal.)
Focally prominent position.
Taken as the subject of egeneto, because of the following kai.
Marked order; why?
Default order for a periphrastic construction.
'There is no-one who...'
In P1 because, if this had been expressed in the passive, 'their fathers' would be focal.
Marked order: why?
Associated with oude ('nor again'), so not preposed.
Homoios precedes the verb unless a content question word precedes it.
Relates to 'this report'. Has 'in all Judea' been preposed for focal prominence?
OR the complex subject is focally prominent.
Focally prominent because anarthrous?
Variants include the addition of the arricle, the addition of de, and ho de (the logical reading).
Marked position.
thetic
Might egeneto be functioning as a main verb here, with 'the appearance of his face' and 'his clothing' as subjects?
Only example in NT, so not possible to know if in P2 or not.
Could be T-H with 56, but the referents of the PPs are different.
If the structure is identificational. If it is thetic, then ekei is an embedded PoD.
Focal.
Usually pre-verb (incorporated).
Preposed to mark switch of attention from 'the nations of the world' back to 'you'.
Treated as accessible from 'treasure', rather than thetic.
Focus particle (common in LXX) that gives prominence to what follows. Often exclusive (all' e: 'but only'; e.g., Amos 7:14, contrast 8:11(.
Default order: noun, modified by participle.
No matrix clause follows.
The reason clause could well be thetic.
Default position if endechetai is an auxiliary.
Pre-N also in 1 Th 2:7. Conforms to Principle of Natural Info Flow?
Tis allows a single clause to introduce a new participant (thetic) and to make a comment about him as topic.
Focal if aware of what the others have said.
Focal: see v. 31.
Could be focal because of v 27.
Variant kai: better, from a discourse point of view.
OR 'man certain ... rich' = split focal consituent in a thetic construction. But why would 'rich' be given prominence?
These are answers to the question, WHAT shall I do?', so I take the foci to be 'to dig' and 'to beg', rather than the main verbs.
Inceptive use of imperfect: 'he started by saying to the first'.
Marked position of panta; see Mt 6:33, etc.
"and he, on his part, as opposed to the patriarch and to Lazarus" (Meyer 1884).
PoD by renewal: new point.
exophoric ref.
PoD to indicate that they, rather than Jesus, are the centre of attention.
Taken as a connective, used as a spacer.
Potentially paraphrastic but, as in 34, esontai is existential.
As with tis, duo allows participants to be introduced (thetic) in the same clause that makes a comment about them as topic.
In contrast with Mt 19, 'the Kingdom of God' has not been established in the immediate context, hence the ambiguity.
Alternatively, 'me' could be contrasting with 'no-one ... except God'.
The rest of the clause is established information.
Default position for object of 'want' = subject of 'rule'.
If 'the way of God' is established info (see Mt 22:16), then it is not focal, but has been pulled forward by the other focal constituent.
Contrasts with the ek-phrase in the previous sentence. Tom Wright uses two clauses to capture the double focus; 'but she contributed out of her poverty, and gave her whole livelihood'.
Focal because of parallel in next line.
Alternatively, in P1 in the next clause (KJV, TNT).
Marked position in relation to tauta.
Relates to 'crowd', not 'betray'.
May be pre-verbal to leave the DFE isolated at the end of the sentence.
Marked encoding for same subject = 'he himself'.
Theoretically, this constituent could also be focal.
May be part of VP.
The previous clause is thetic, so, if sun auto: had been part of that clause, it should have preceded the subject.
Focally prominent if the rest of the proposition is presupposed.
Alternatively, 'very early' is in P1, with e:lthon postposed as the DFE.
Lexham: 'to his [own] home'.
Is this focally prominent because it is followed by taute:n?
Treated as part of the VP.
OR: panta is in P1, with 'through (him)' focally prominent (P2).
Head noun followed by participial clause: default order.
Complex orienter highlights speech, but use of historical present and perfect point forward to more to come.
Could be the more remote referent, but could be indicating that the centre of attention is going to be John, rather than Jesus.
Clarificatory: singular verb.
In Ps 69:9, the subject is in P2 but, because it is arthrous here, it appears to be in P1.
anarthrous
In the sense of 'someone else' (other than 'us').
Some commentators consider 'in this' to be cataphoric, referring to v. 38. It would then be in P2, which violates the principle that P2 never precedes P1.
Marked position in John (also 1:41, 5:43, 7:18).
'judgment in all its forms' (Godet).
Many scholars: cataphoric.
Order conforms to Principle of Natural Information Flow: the disciples were visible to the crowd.
On the assumption that v. 60 implies that they were being caused to stumble.
'arrest' was activated in v. 32.
As in 20:31, simple form of graphw (rather than default periphrastic) suggests that constituent is in P2 (Variant has participle focally prominent.)
If cleft, could be in P1 in second part.
If cleft, then in P1 in the second part.
But see 19:10-11.
Variant: hos.
Why the split constituent?
Or the DFE of the matrix clause.
In P2 because twice post-verb in John.
The focus is on 'with', not 'you'.
P1 reading makes 'much' the DFE. P2 reading seems to fit better with the following clause being the reason.
I'd have expected 'sorrow' to be focal (thetic), but the article implies that it is the topic.
default pre-vb.
Order conforms to Principle of Natural Info Flow: Peter was the last person mentioned.
Split constituent, even though not focal.
Order conforms to Principle of Natural Info Flow: 'him' is more established than 'you'.
But see v 11.
Order conforms to Principle of Natural Info Flow: Pilate more established than chief priests.
Order probably conforms to Principle of Natural Info Flow: cross more established than the bodies.
Order conforms to Principle of Natural Info Flow: Pilate more established than Joseph.
Why final? Position (& Lexham) imply that DFE.
Or right-dislocated for clarification.
Could be focally prominent/a foil for the second volume.
See JB Phililips: 'He gave instructions, through the Holy Spirit, to the special messengers of his choice'.
On the assumption that they were in or near Jerusalem. However, Luke may view the reference to Jerusalem as new, as far as Theophilus is concerned.
Is this phrase split, relating to 'two men'? See also 10:30.
DFE because topical subject is split?
Assuming that Luke would expect the apostles to be performing them.
The order suggests that arton is the DFE. If so, why?
Thetic, but tis allows a comment to be made about him.
All the info in this clause is more or less established.
Default position between dei and infinitive.
Narrow focus.
Topical subject postposed.
Alternatively, 'of years' could be in P1, in which case the topical subject would be classified as postposed.
Could be focally prominent, too. UBS notes 'confusion' about this v.
Spacer, to highlight what follows.
May be part of the VP.
Thetic, but tis allows a comment to be made about him.
Order conforms to Principle of Natural Info Flow: 'these words' is more established than the subject.
Always clause final, so not marked as DFE.
Final to separate the two pronouns.
Thetic, so both subject and second location are focal.
Infinite absolute in Ex 3:7: 'I have surely seen'.
This analysis reflects Ex 3:7 MTT & LXX, even though, theoretically, the verb could be the DFE.
Not focal (contrast NRSV). Switch from 'the tent/tabernacle of Moloch'.
Norm: immediately post-verb
thetic
Should be thetic. But see v 39.
Could be thetic: unless there is someone to guide me.
ouketi normally pre-vb.
Subject = infinitival clause. I am assuming that auton is in default position about the initial verb, rather than in P1 in relation to engizein. However, see Petron in 9:32.
Preposed to isolate and give focal prominence to the thetic subject at the end of the sentence?
Focally prominent only if the presupposition is 'it is necessary for you to do something'.
Not focally prominent; order conforms to Principle of Natural Info Flow.
The cataphoric usage has good commentary support. I wonder, though, whether eis touto could not mean, 'for this same purpose' (anaphoric).
Relates to first participle, not second.
Not preceded by an article. Commentaries usually treat this as part of the P1 constituent, though.
Thetic subject, but tis allows him to become the topic about whom a comment is then made.
The topical subjects could be in P1, too.
Thetic subject, but becomes the topic of the rest of the sentence.
The article suggests that 'God' is not focal.
Is this phrase split, relating to 'man'? See also 1:10.
Or right-dislocated in relation to 37.
Focal if 'turned to the Lord' is the expected result from the previous two sentences.
Rather than going to the gate.
See v 20 for a similar time expression clause-final.
P1 if understood to mean 'in the same way'.
If this word begins the next clause, then it would be focally prominent and split into three parts.
Unclear why the anarthrous locative precedes the articular object, unless thematic.
Following NRSV. However, 'in the synagogues' could be in default position at the end of the previous clause.
Always anarthrous in nominative.
May be default order when followed by rel cl - see 20:25.
The article may suggest that it was expected that it was Paul who had the vision.
Periphrastic imperfect with locative anchor (default order).
On the other two occasions, this adverb follows the verb.
Object of both aux and infin, so default order.
OR could be focally prominent: 'THAT was how Paul left them'.
Luke treats Gallio as accessible info.
If parsed this when, then translate 'with the brothers'. See Mt 15:32 & Mk 8:2.
NRSV 'Now there came to Ephesus a Jew named Apollos...'.
Established info, so underlining the violation of Natural Info Flow.
Marked order, possibly to allow 'saying' to be immediately followed by the content of the speech.

Bailey (Thetic Constructions) considers this sentence to have narrow focus, which is why the participle is final. Alternatively, touto poiountes is a topical subject, postposed to give prominence to the focal predicate that precedes it..
Lake and others note that this could mean 'according to the power of the Lord'. The order of constituents is consistent with such a suggestion.
Thetic subject but, with tis, becomes the topic about which a comment is made. Preposed because attention temporarily switches to him from Paul.
Foil for next clause.
May be in default position.
May be default order when followed by rel cl; see 15:36.
Marked order, with time followed by thetic subject, though not clause final.
'to be finished the days' is the subject of egeneto.
Always in this position.
Always pre-verb, but could be focally prominent.
Marked because modifies 'quiet', not verb.
Alternatively' there' is in P2 (narrow focus): 'THERE is where you will be told about...'.
'More than 40' is focally prominent because the Principle of Natural Information Flow is violated.
With 'go up, 'to Jerusalem' is nuclear, whereas 'from Caesarea' is an adjunct; hence the order.
Narros focus, with the presupposition, 'be judged by me concerning these things'. 'There' contrasts with 'here'.
Relates to final verb, not mello:n.
Default order ('to Damascus' is nuclear).
'When we had ALL fallen to the ground' (NRSV).
Intermediate step.
If 'the great learning' is in P1, then why is it split by 'me'?
Very marked order. 'It was with such kindness that Julius treated Paul...' (cleft, with two P1's in second part?).
Foil for 'the bay'.
Foil for the centurion.
A foil for 'viper', perhaps, as it would look like a stick.
Not, perhaps, the expected addressees.
Always pre-verb, but could be focally prominent.
'Thus' is focal, with the rest presupposed (Rome is arthrous - contrast v 16).
Narrow focus.
Narrow focus.
Default order: inner periphery - outer periphery.
LXX, translating Hebrew verb + infinitive absolute.
Focus of marked construction is 'not having', not 'law'.
If focal, I'd have expected 'God' to be anarthrous.
Conforms to Principle of Natural Info Flow.
Presumably conforms to Principle of Natural Info Flow, with 'Abraham' more established than 'faith'.
Default position immed after verb.

If the variant reading with the negative particle ou is followed, then the initial participial clause is backgrounded in relation to what follows. If the UBS reading is followed, then it is focally prominent.
Arthrous: encyclopaedic knowledge.
refocus; all the information was established in 6, so 'died for us' is presupposed. 'It was while we were STILL SINNERS that CHRIST dies for us'.
Anarthrous because of the shift from a specific sin (12) to sin in general.
As in v 15. Or might the focus be on 'trespass'?
In NRSV, 'sin' is focal.
Embedded DFE w/in focal constit.
Not marked for embedded focal prominence, as always in this position when meaning 'same'.
The presence of the article suggests that, at least to begin with, these areas are viewed as sub-categories of 'the good' (v. 9b).
A/c Moo, the final 'evil' is in a chiastic arrangement with v 17a.
Could be in P2 (see v 1), but arthrous .
This analysis takes 'one another' as a foil for 'this' in 13b.

In the Hebrew of Isa 11:10, the first line has 'amim, whereas the second has goyim, which would allow 'on him' to be a PoD, with goyim focally prominent. In Greek, though, it is difficult to see how ethne: could be focally prominent in the second line. (NIV treats 'on him' as focal.)
Although NIV and NRSV treat this constituent as a PoD, the focus on v. 20 is 'where Christ was not named', which suggests that it is focal.
Because anarthrous, may be a series of 3 P2 constituents: 'and made known... ...through the prophetic Scriptures ...a/c to a command of the eternal God ...for obedience of faith to all the Gentiles'.
In the Hebrew, the verb is the DFE.
emphatic prominence
Order conforms to Principle of Natural Info Flow ('you' are more established than the subject).
Different commenators treat houto:s as a connective (Lenski), as a PoD (ICC), or as emphatically prominent (Lightfoot).
In P2 because it is anarthrous.
Although the order is the same as in 12a, the contrast is now between panta and hupo tinos.
Narrow focus: It is not the WIFE who has authority over her own body, but the HUSBAND; etc.
I chose P1, rather than P2, because of houto:s in the next clause.
This could be read, 'and CIRCUMCISION is nothing...'. Because of the article, though, 'uncircumcision' is probably the topic.
If 'what he desires' is viewed as established info, then it could be in P1.
Always pre-verb, but could be focally prominent.
Preposing even before subject of 'ought': extra prominence.
Always pre-verb, but could be focally prominent.
'You yourselves' -- ICC.
Norm is for pantes to be anarthrous.
Right-dislocated for clarification.
I myself.
Paul may well be quoting from what the Corinthians wrote to him (commentators), which would explain the narrow focus of these clauses.

There is an anarthrous variant. If anarthrous, then 'Christ' would be focally prominent (in P2) and 'the head of very man' would be in P1. However, this does not explain why pantos andros is preposed.
Default order, with estin as an enclitic?
'many weak and sick': thetic subject.
Articular, so less prominent than 'however you were being led'. Could the phrase even be a PoD to indicate that it was not the idols, but something more demonic, that resulted in them being led away?
Default position of mallon is before the constituent it governs.
Gloss should be 'and not even'.
Verbs are established info from v 1.
Conforms to Principle of Natural Info Flow.
'Our proclamation' and 'your faith' are still established (comparre 11).
Here and in Rom 3:29, the constituent to which monon relates is in P2.
'Through man' is non-established. But does the parallelism with 22 affect the analysis?
Always pre-verb, but could be focally prominent.
May be default position in the light of what follows.
Relates to 'gift', not 'give thanks'.
As relating to 'glory', not 'Amen': "glory to God by the ministry of Paul and his co-workers" (Exegetical Helps).
A minority of commentators relate this clause to what follows.
Relating back to vv 6-7.
Default is pre-vb.
If the preceding adverbs ('more frequently, far more, often' are focal, then 'five (times)' might well be focally prominent, too.
'Behold, this will be the THIRD time that I am coming...' (AG). Alternatively, treat triton touto as a single, focal constituent: 'Here I am, ready to come to you this third time' (NRSV).
If cleft, could be in P2 in second part.
Should be PoD for what follows, but lacks a main clause.
Continuative relative clause.
'How is it that [the Gentiles you compel...']?'

Vaz (p. 37), ff Parunak (1992): "Thus the rebuke extends from 2:14 through 2:21, and also serves as the theological stepping stone for Paul to launch [in 3:1] into the development of his main thesis in 1:11."
Every other example of ean me:: 'unless' => only justified by works of law if (first) have faith in JC. This is then corrected in the latter part of the sentence.
Like makarios, behaves like a verb.
In Lev 18:5, the subject is in P1. Here, in contrast, it could be in P2 to contrast doing with believing.
Variant reading, with 'Hagar' omitted, makes more sense! Otherwise, why are 'Sinai' and 'Mount' reversed?
Default is pre-verb.
Alternative: 'crucify' is the DFE, with 'with the passions and the lusts' right-dislocated.

If theos were thematic, it would be the only instance of anarthrous theos in Galatians that was not focally prominent. If converted from passive to active, it would be the DFE. 'No one makes a fool of God' (The Message).
Default position with kairos? See 1 Tim 2:6., 6:15, Tit 1:3.
Not DFE because the same word was used in v 9.
Could be focally prominent (split focus).
'hope' mentioned in 1:18; note a- in next lkne.
Implied by context.
Part of a constituent that contains non-established info. The rest of the proposition is established info.
If this phrase were the DFE, then it would be the only instance in Ephesians where an arthrous reference to God was focal.
Doublet suggests that verbs are focally prominent.
May be a switch from remourse with ref to God.
Negated verb might be focally prominent, too.
Taken as thetic see 4:29, 31; continues in v 4.
Anarthrous/focally prominent because of implied contrast.
Not DFE because same root as earlier.
Anaphoric in the first instance, but then amplified.
Anarthrous, so focally prominent.
Marked order, possibly because the default position immediately after the verb is already occupied by 'me'.
Pronominal subject after P2 adds prominence.
I am assuming that ta should be omitted.
Parallel to the en-phrases in 5; understood egenHthhmen.
If cleft, then in P1 in the second part.
A second PoD.
Ambiguous because of pantote in the previous sentence.
May be default position with kairos; see Gal 6:9, 1 Tim 6:15, Tit 1:3.
May be default position with kairos; see Gal 6:9 & 1 Tim 2:6, Tit 1:3.
Taken as left-dislocated because citing another part of the quote.
By adding 'even', NIV gives focal prominence to 'while he goes about his business'. However, the constituent is articular, so it is more likely that the verb is postposed for focal prominence.
P2, but then becomes topical: 'Let there be no-one who, on being tempted, says...'.
Default is pre-verb.
Anarthrous: focally prominent (probably because 'transgressor' is contrastively prominent).
1st clause: 'your faith' is more established (18b) than 'without the works'. 2nd clause: 'from the works' is more established (18c) than 'the faith'.
Following SSA, It take this as the complement of 'let him show by his good conduct': 'that his works (are) in the MEEKNESS of wisdom'.

De: distinct point, so translate singular karpos as 'harvest' (next stage after 'fruits'. God's Word for the Nations translates, 'A harvest that has God's approval. [anarthrous cos not uniquely identifiable] 'comes from the peace [P2] plantedby peacemakers'.
Anarthrous also in Lk 1:76, 2 Cor 8:21 & Lk 1:15 (articular variant), so may be a frozen expression, rather than focally prominent.
The subject could be thetic, rather than topical.
This proposition could be thetic.
Unless this PP is modifying elpida.
Conditional clause may relate to previous span of time, not to what follows.
As in Acts 19:36, this position may well be default.
Anarthrous: appositive is more prominent than articular (see 9). Focal in relation to 'the genuineness of your faith'.
Anarthrous = focally prominent (see 7).
Anarthrous + articular: descriptive
accesible thru ref to salvation.
Default for Christos in 1 Peter is anarthrous.
Focus particularly on eis.
Tied back to t testing of your faith Y subsequent glory (v 7).
May be anarthrous because thinking of NT manifestation of Holy Spirit at Pentecost. Either way, focal.
3-12 (part of the same sentence) are backgrounded in relation to these exhortations, if dio is taken as introducing a continuative relative cl.
Hapax.
Previous mention in v 2. Anarthrous because focal within 'since you are children of OBEDIENCE'.
accessible because of preaching of Gospel, relieving ignorance.
articular because shared knowledge? Accessible because they have been saved/born again, therefore needed to change.
However this phrase is exegeted, the key word (DFE) is 'holy'.
Identificational articulation/narrow focus. 'In all conduct' is part of the presupposition, but has been made explicit.
Position probably gives more prominence to mataias.
Because 2 modifiers pre-head N, postposed, but still anarthrous.
19 could be treated as split focus with the negative in 18b.
anarthrous appositive,for focal prominence.
established (v 5), but contrastively focal.
Peters (p. 257) claims that Art Attrib N is the ONLY order found in 1 Peter, 1:25b is an exception, but order in prob still default.
anarthrous: focally prominent (again at end of verse).
equivalent of non-restrictive relative clause, so on separate line.
Established (3) but focally prominent. Note the chiasm with 'glory' in the next line.
Or appositive to the ek constituent.
Although splitting could be simply cos coordinative, allows second part to relate to 25.
anarthrous in Hebrew, but arthrous in LXX.
Heb & LXX have tou theou. May be anarthrous cos contrastively prominent (or translating YHWH).
Although older versions have this constituent in P1, its anarthrous nature implies that it is in P2 (see TEV).
PoD by renewal (see touto in 1:25), introducing a distinct pt.
Anarthrous because different from 4.
Other NT books use with article when topical.
Substantival in LXX Hebrew, in which case, appositive..
Counterpoint to main point in 7b.
See entimon in v 6. See also 1:7 (relating to believers).
stumble by being disoobedient to the Word. Or (KJV) 'to hhe word' relates to 'stumble'.
I take this to be a relative pronoun, introducing the name of Hosea's daughter (Loruhamah - 1:6). If read as an article, then appositive to the previoius pair.
Mark Dubis says that, because in accusative, should relate to following verb.
plural: overtones of inclusiveness: 'whichever'. Might even be in apposition to 'fleshy lusts'.
Or P1, not relating to following participle.
Same order in Jas 3:16, but opposite order in Jas 1:17.
Or, perhaps, dia is focally prominent.
Articular constrains readers to relate 'ignorance' and 'foolish' to something in context (e.g. v 12). See also 1:14.
Appears to relate to 'evil doers' in 2:14, rather than to 2:1.
Switch from perfective (aorist) to imperfective (present) probably means the first command is generic and the others, specific instances of 'honouring everyone'.
May well relate back to 2:13-16, rather than v 17.
anarthrous: focally prominent.
Order as in LXX. In Hebrew, 'violence' is in P2. Because of ref to sinning in v 21, though, could be in P1.
Constrained to be related to what has been previously been said.
LXX 1st person plural.
LXX: 'we were led astray',
Usually pre-head noun, though there are exceptions. Also, Art Atrib N is default.
Let yours be not... but...
Articular constrains readers to relate to something in context = earlier in the chapter.
Articular: readers instructed to relate it to known info.
Anarthrous: focally prominent.
Could be for clarification.
Anarthrous because vocative?
Always initial.
Could be cataphoric, pointing forward to the hina clause.
LXX also anarthrous. Ellipsis of verb and article.
Anarthrous construct form in Hebrew.
See Isaiah 8:13 LXX. First time Christos is articular in 1 Peter. Constrains Christon to be related back to something in context = kurion.
Articular cos apologian makes it accessible.
I take the anarthrous infinitival clause as the complement of kreitton, rather than its subject. Suffering for doing good: more prominent than if it had been an embedded subject.
Could be related back to 14?
Arthrous if 'pneumati (18) is taken to mean 'in the realm of the spirit', which makes 'the spirits in prison' to be accessed, in line with extra- bilbical Jewish literature of the time.
Understood as a post-nuclear adverbial participle (Grudem).

Arthrous because accessed by 'the spirits in prison'. Grudem cites Jewish extra-biblical literature to show a unanimous emphasis on God's waiting for sinners to repent, and connecting his patience specifically with the time of the flood.
Not same referent as in 16, broader.
Assuming that relates to swsei, rather than 'pledge'.
As in 3:19, not specifically 'in his flesh', but 'in the bodily realm'.
Suffering in flesh is a sub-group of remaining in flesh.
Postposed in anticipation of 3. Not focally prominent.
Taking 'the desire of the Gentiles' (articular) to refer to v 2.
Used more specifically than in 2 (generic).
Could be embedded DFE.
Referent is not same as in 5.
Alludes to Prov 10:12 MTT, but reverse order.
Note switch back to plural in following participial clause. So relates only to kathws clause, but more prominent than if in default position after kathws.
Order corresponds to Principle of NIF.
Arthrous ref to concept not mentioned for a while implies that the referent is thematic over a larger span.
Focus is eph, not whole constituent. Altve: subject is focal, but arthrous (contrast Is 11:2).
Prominent because ff negative particle, but not focal.
Always found in this position in NT.
Instructs readers to find uniquely identifiable referent in mental representation.
In isolation, order is ambiguous, but 'sufferings' contrasts with 'glory' in next clause.
Conforms to Natural Info Flow; norm for Peter.
Second focus; see 'as GOD would have it' (ESV).
Split focus, but established info.
Sign of honour, consistent with honour-shame theme in book.
Vocative, equivalent of PoD. Variants have the article (with de or de kai).
Dubis finds a parallel between this passage and Ezek 9. In 9:6, zaqen is used to refer to both elders and old man. The absence of the article opens the way for the same to be true here.
Variant because kurios is anarthrous in LXX. Topical, so theos should have article!
In Hebrew, the verb is clearly focal. If 'lording it over' (v 3) presupposes being proud, then the verb is the DFE here, too.
Articular relates to suffering - see Dubis.
'You', rather than God, are the topic: distinct point. 'God' is default propositional topic, which is cancelled (?) by P1 constituent.
Adjectival usage - several grammarians treat it as such. This explains the absence of the article with diabolos (variant exists).
Taken as an embedded question, so default order.
the same experiences of the devil as a roaring lion; viz., of the sufferings.
Particularly if anarthrous.
anarthrous: multi-faceted, could be looking forward, rather than backward.
The appositive constituent could be a continuation of the initial P2 constituent. Within the apposition, is topical.
Default position for interrogative.
Anarthrous; focally prominent?
See NRSV.
Alternative: anaphoric, closing the inclusio begun at v 3.
Could be in P2, but see 4:15.
If cleft, could be in P1 in second part.
Because 20 begins with hoti (some MSS), en touto: could well be cataphoric (even though supported by very few commentators).
Other MSS: ho ti...
As in 2:22, could be in P1 or P2.
Refocus on established information
Taken as a separate point ('I wish to remind you how...').
Default order, because en pneumati is the complement (core constituent) of egenome:n.
Theoretically, ho he:lios is preposed in relation to phainei. However, it may be that, in clauses governed by ho:s, the default position for the subject is immediately after ho:s.
There is an arthrous reference to endurance in v. 2, so 'have' could be prominent. However, the absence of the article suggests that 'endurance' is focally prominent.

The order is marked, but is complicated by the fact that 'until end' is anarthrous, whereas 'my works' is arthrous. Assuming that 'until end' parallels 'until I come' (v. 25), though, the order of constituents may still be judged to conform to the Principle of Natural Information Flow, with 'my works' the DFE.
An alternative analysis has 'themselves' as the object of 'declaring.
'Them' over against other matters?
Always clause final.
Norm is pre-vb.
Maybe asingle focal constituent: 'a voice from the throne'?
Identificational - see 6b.
Thetic.
